Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Storage:  enable setting blob metadata" (#6001) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Storage:  enable setting metadata" (#6000) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Question: Is it allowed to specify more than one PackageType ("dependency" + user defined) for search filtering purposes?" (#5999) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
@Apollo3zehn commented on [Wed May 23 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6966)

My applications allows to install extensions that are hosted in a NuGet repository. Because this repository contains not only extensions for my application, but also completely different ones (which is the case for e.g. NuGet.org), I would like to specify a second PackageType to filter the [PackageSearchResource](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/4eed67e7e159796ae486d2cca406b283e23b6ac8/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/Resources/PackageSearchResource.cs) search results. 

From point of view of my application everything works. But I cannot install these extensions anymore in Visual Studio or using the CLI because of more than one package type. I get something like "The paket 'NugetPackageTypeTest 1.0.0' has multiple package types. This is not supported."

I would also like to avoid to enforce specific package name prefixes or certain tags. I think the package type would be the natural choice. But since this does not work, my question is, is there another option for the above described scenario?

---

@zhili1208 commented on [Thu May 24 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6966#issuecomment-391890324)

this scenario is not supported, Could you split your package into two packages? one contains all the staff for extension, and another contains everything for dependency use. and let extension package depends on the dependency package.

---

@Apollo3zehn commented on [Fri May 25 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6966#issuecomment-392085678)

Thanks for your suggestions. Although I don't like the idea to have twice as many projects for such a simple requirement, I tried to simply duplicate the packages (call `dotnet pack` twice) such that they only differ in `PackageId` and `PackageType`. But unfortunately it turned out that a query string like 
https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=&skip=0&take=15&prerelease=true&packageTypeFilter=OneDasExtension&semVerLevel=2.0.0 does not work on Nuget.org or myget.org, i.e. the results are not filtered by `packageTypeFilter`.

I also tried to modify the `q` parameter itself (according to [this](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Search-by-Package-Type-and-Query-Language-Surfacing) document), to get a query like:
https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=PackageType%3AOneDasExtension&skip=0&take=15&prerelease=true&semVerLevel=2.0.0, which is equal to `PackageType:OneDasExtension` but this also failed. 

_Info: Right now there is no package of type `OneDasExtension `hosted on Nuget.org. Therefore this query is not good for testing. But if you want to filter by e.g. `DotnetTool`, try this query: https://www.nuget.org/packages?q=PackageType%3ADotnetTool or this one https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=PackageType%3ADotnetTool&skip=0&take=20&prerelease=true&semVerLevel=2.0.0. Both versions do not give correct results. **I think the search API described [here](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Search-by-Package-Type-and-Query-Language-Surfacing) is not (fully) implemented. Is that correct?**_

Because none of these queries worked, I switched back to use a special tag instead. This works much better but also not perfectly. If I execute the following query (`id:HDF tags:OneDAS`) against Nuget.org, I get a single result:
https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=id%3AOneDas%20tags%3A+HDF&skip=0&take=20&prerelease=true&semVerLevel=2.0.0
It seems that this is an AND operation, **which is what I want**. 

But if I instead execute this query against myget.org, I get too many results:
https://www.myget.org/F/onedas/api/v3/query?q=id%3AOneDas%20tags%3A+HDF&skip=0&take=20&prerelease=true&semVerLevel=2.0.0
Here it seems that myget applies an OR operation: either the package has `id: HDF` **or** the package contains a tag named OneDAS.

Do you know where this discrepancy comes from or is there another possibility to make searching for certain packages more precise / reliable, either using PackageType, Tags or something else?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Allow NuGet account to signup with work and school accounts" (#5997) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm forced to upgrade NuGet account to use Microsoft Account.

Microsoft Account does not allow me to use me e-mail address, because it is "work or school account".

NuGet must allow accounts to use work and school accounts.

PS: I cannot create custom `@outlook.com` address because no matter what I enter, I always get validation error that account name is not available.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet restore, with HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY (with user/password) broken again" (#6978) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @tebeco on May 28, 2018 14:11_

## Steps to reproduce
* setup an NTLM proxy
* add a Nuget.Config with 

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <config>
    <add key="dependencyVersion" value="Highest" />
    <add key="no_proxy"    value="*.yourCorp" />
  </config>
 <packageSources>
    <!--To inherit the global NuGet package sources remove the <clear/> line below -->
    <clear />
    <add key="nuget" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="corpFeed" value="https://yourfeed.yourCorp" />
...
 </packageSources>
</configuration>
```
* Setup proxy in your shell
```
$> set HTTP_PROXY=http://user:password@your-proxy:port
$> set HTTPS_PROXY=http://user:password@your-proxy:port

$> dotnet restore
```

* try nuget for fun
```
$> nuget
NuGet Version: 4.6.0.4971

$> >nuget restore YOUR_PROJECT.csproj
 .... IT WORKS
```

soooooo anyone know how to make `dotnet restore` works behind an NTLM proxy ?
##### NUGET is OK
##### PAKET is OK (without any env var)
##### DOTNET ... was ok ... with only proxy URL
##### DOTNET is KO without env var
##### DOTNET is KO with env var
##### DOTNET is KO with env var + user / password in the NTLM proxy url (no special character in either user or password)

## Expected  behavior
... it should work

## Actual behavior
* All internal feed nugets are OK and restored
* dotnet still fails behind proxy

```
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.300-rc1-008673\NuGet.targets(114,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json. [D:\xxxxxx\xxxxxx.csproj]
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.300-rc1-008673\NuGet.targets(114,5): error :   Response status code does not indicate success: 407 (authenticationrequired). [D:\xxxxxx\xxxxxx.csproj]
```


## Environment data
```
>dotnet --info
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   2.1.300-rc1-008673
 Commit:    f5e3ddbe73

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.15063
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.300-rc1-008673\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 2.1.0-rc1
  Commit:  eb9bc92051

.NET Core SDKs installed:
  2.1.4 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.100 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.101 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.102 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.103 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.104 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.105 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.200 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.201 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  2.1.300-rc1-008673 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]

.NET Core runtimes installed:
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.All 2.1.0-rc1-final [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.All]
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 2.1.0-rc1-final [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 2.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Packaging multitargeting framework project results in one target framework package" (#6977) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
I have created .NET standard 2.0 class library project in my application. However I also need this library to be available in .NET Framework 4.7.1 project. To make it possible, I changed target framework to target frameworks of netstandard2.0;net471 to have this build two ways. Build/Rebuild itself in VS works fine - two folders for different frameworks are beeing generated. However, when I try to create nuget package using NuGet.Build.Packaging, it creates only one framework folder in the package. I was trying the version of 0.2.3 and latest release 0.2.5-pr160.1 of NuGet.Build.Packaging. What should I do to get package for both frameworks?

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):
NuGet.exe 4.5.1.4879
VS UI 15.7.2
Package Manager Console 4.7.0.5212
.NET Framework 4.7.2
OS version: Win 10 v1803

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create .NetStandard 2.0 class library project

2. Modify .csproj adding net471 to target framework (remember to rename TargetFramework to TargetFrameworks)

3. Rebuild package

4. Create Nuget package with Nuget.Build.Packaging

Regards,
Ariel Zakrzewski

one of the package always failed with the error: 

`System.Net.Http.HttpRequestException: Response status code does not indicate success: 403 (The specified API key is invalid, has expired, or does not have permission to access the specified package.).`

I can manually upload this package via NuGet.org and use it in Visual Studio without problem, so the package id should be fine.
Another package works well, so the API Key set in my VSTS account is also correct and not expired

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "OOTB .net core SDK 2.1.200 console- and class library projects compile with errors" (#6975) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @stigperez on May 27, 2018 7:55_

## Steps to reproduce

1. Download and install "dotnet-sdk-2.1.200-win-gs-x64.exe"
2. Open a command prompt, create a project directory under c: and navigate to the newly created directory
3. Execute "dotnet new classlib"
4. Execute "dotnet build"

## Expected  behavior
The project compiles without errors

## Actual behavior
The command prompt displays 24 compile errors in the two categories "The type or namespace name '[namespace]' could not be found" and "Predefined type '[type]' is not defined or imported". The referenced [namespace] and [type] are all referring to "System" or derived types of "System"

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:
.NET Command Line Tools (2.1.200)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.1.200
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  2edba8d7f1

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.17134
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.200\

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.7
  Build    : 2d61d0b043915bc948ebf98836fefe9ba942be11

All my findings have been made on a newly restored laptop running Windows 10 Pro. I was able to generate a working class library on another laptop using the same procedure, and after comparing the two project folders there are several differences, mostly in obj\project.assets.json. I have attached the [two project folders](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/files/2042347/compile-test.zip) so you should be able to view the differences yourselves. Most noticeably I will simply mention the "version" key under "frameworks" seems to be invalid syntax and also a lot of dll-references are missing from the same file.

It may still be an issue on my laptop but any help would be appreciated :-)

_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#9353_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Address perf cost of discovering plugins" (#6744) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
"Discovering" the plugins to create credential providers is costly, mostly because currently the plugin discoverer does the verification of the plugin.

The lookup and signature validation of the plugins should not be done until the plugins are actually needed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Protocol Cleanup - timeouts, plugin ordering, instantiation xplat" (#6706) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
- [x] timeouts 
- [x] plugin ordering - outcome none in the convention based plugins. It's irrelevant. For ordering users should use env variables.
-  [ ] cross plat instantiation.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Consider how to solve the credential plugin + proxy scenario" (#6923) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet itself has some very primitive proxy support. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuget-config-file

In the past, the old credential provider did not have any proxy support. 

There are 2 options here:
- NuGet passes the proxy settings at/sometime after the initialization
- The Credential provider reads the NuGet config for the proxy settings. 

Need to analyze the pros and cons for each. 

//cc @keithrob @pspill @rrelyea

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org API rate limits for package updates" (#24) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4679|

We have been working on improving the package submission workflow to reduce the overall time it takes to publish the package (right from package push/upload) till it's available for consumption and search. 

As mentioned on our [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180201/NuGet-package-publishing-workflow-behind-the-scenes.html), the package availability gets degraded multi fold whenever there is a large number package uploads/updates by a single owner that clogs the package submission pipeline. Until we are able to scale to handle the large submission rate, in the short-term, we plan to reduce the rate limits for package pushes or deletes (unlist) per user.

The current [documented rate limits](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits#package-push-and-unlist) will be updated to the following new limits once implemented. This change will go live, **soon** (within a week or two):

## Package Push and Unlist

| API | Limit Type | Limit Value | API usecase | 
|:---|:---|:---|:--- |
**PUT** `/api/v2/package` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **250 / hour** | Upload a new NuGet package (version) via v2 push endpoint 
**DELETE** `/api/v2/package/{id}/{version}` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **50 / hour** | Unlist a NuGet package (version) via v2 endpoint

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet cross plat authentication plugin" (#23) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The **NuGet cross plat authentication plugin** feature spec is ready for **review**:

|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|[NuGet cross plat authentication plugin ](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/NuGet-cross-plat-authentication-plugin)|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6486|
